name: Kepler-1180
scenarioDescription:
The Kepler-1180 Exoplanetary System


Overview

Kepler-1180 is a star with 1.09 times the mass of the Sun, and 1.14 times its radius. It is located NaN light years away from the solar system and is estimated to be 3.09 billion years old, as compared to the Sun which is roughly 4.6 billion years old.

Kepler-1180 is known to have undefined exoplanets in orbit around it.


Exoplanets in the Kepler-1180 system


Kepler-1180 b

Kepler-1180 b was discovered by the undefined observatory using the transit method. Its semi-major axis is 0.12 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The mass of Kepler-1180 b is 4.611000000000001 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-1180 b is 1.99 that of Earth. At 4.611000000000001 Earth masses, Kepler-1180 b is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system Kepler-1180, which contains undefined planets and was discovered by undefined.
